data.author: Tyke68
data.content: As I stated earlier I have just had a conversation with Mr Brown. He had contacted me asking if we could talk. So the bit that people want to hear The company has being trying to engage with partners for a phase 2 partner. One of the technical issues has been the trial was being extended and one patient is still enrolled. I think that is great news for the patient. We do own the data but MCW will publish the results. These results haven’t been completed yet, patient still alive. Possible partners obviously want the phase 1 results which have not been fully written up yet and Mr Brown couldn’t give a definitive date for when they would be. It is MCW not IB that is publishing the data. The cost of the trial was hoped to be $2.5m with a start date of approximately in a year’s time and taking about 3 years to complete. Which the company did  also look at self funding. The company has been talking to an institution/hospital about partnering with the trial. However, the other people never actually committed and a decision kept being delayed. What I hadn’t realised is how the clinical trial process is quite competitive with oncologist’s deciding who to refer their patient for a trial. As GBM is quite a niche disease (thankfully) and there being other trials available it is quite competitive. So last week at a board meeting and the non decision from the prospective partner a decision was taken to concentrate on the core business as this has been suffering due to the GBM trial. (We have commented previously how MS is trying to do too much) So my understanding is due to the lack of commitment from a prospective partner, the results still not being published, the competitiveness of clinical trials, oncologists choice, time the trial would take to complete we have stopped it to concentrate on the core IB business. (As stated in the RNS this could change I assume, let’s see how much interest the results generate I would guess) We do own the data. After hearing this I personally agree with that decision. Truetide - discussed briefly and TB believes this is a wise future investment for the company. The board are hoping to share a comprehensive strategy update soon, hopefully February. Mr Brown has subsequently messaged  (after the meeting) to say the EAP is ongoing for now. Did I believe Mr Brown, the simple answer is yes I do. Do I now think the right decision was made re the trial, yes I do. Do I now wish we had been given more information in the last update, yes but they were rushing after the board meeting to update us with regards their decision. Will I keep investing in IBAI, yes Have I bought the Porsche yet, no I would like to take this opportunity to thank Mr Brown for giving me the chance to talk to him. I hope I have given an accurate account of our conversation. Apologies if I have got any details wrong. I hope members of this board find this new information helpful. Personall

data.author: mallettp
data.content: If you believe GaM and the associated IP/PRV has value, then it does not take too much imagination to realize that a placing at sub 1p now would allow "harvesting"  of some of that asset value. The only way to prevent this would be to vote against a Share Capital Reorganisation. To pass a Capital Reorganisation (Share Subdivision), IBAI must achieve at least 75% of the votes cast at a General Meeting. Given the holding of the largest minority shareholder, Truetide (72,415,862), you would need around 25 million votes against.

data.author: Tyke68
data.content: If you look at the trades since Friday mid morning there has been far more buys compared to sells but the sp is still doing it’s normal up or down 10 percent. I suspect those who have had enough have already sold up by now. Is the company only worth just over £1m? Absolutely not. Look at how it was valued before we got engrossed by the GAM trial. Several people have always said the imaging side was the money generator. I didn’t believe them and hoped it was the trial (it may still be). I was wrong. I think we will just keep getting small fluctuations in the sp and people quietly building a position whilst we await the shareholder update, trial results, annual report and anything else we don’t know about. For those posters who have left, goodbye and thank you. For those new to the board or are still hanging in there let’s see what we hear in the next 3 months or so. And good luck. United we stand Thanks T

data.content: So it's business as normal, having swallowed the bait, hook line and sinker but at a greatly reduced share price with about as much hope of anything  positive occuring in 2026,2027,2028 bar a miracle by the sounds  of it.. Might as well pop down your local bookmakers and sit at the slot machines, the payout is likely to be on par I guess. Good Luck.

data.author: biffbaffboff
data.content: Many thanks Tyke.  Hopefully it's made TB and co more aware of how frustrated some of us are, and going forward we will get a bit more updates and a roadmap. The global Organ-on-a-chip market size was estimated at USD 157.3 million in 2024 and is projected to reach USD 952.4 million by 2030.  CN Bio seems to be the big UK company with recent investments totalling $21m.  With the likely future of animal testing being phased out, this could be something to be in, along side the current imaging side.  Hopefully they can better concentrate on the core businesses.
